title: 105_hr963
content:
The Workplace Fairness Act of 1997 prohibits discrimination based on factors other than job performance in employment. Quotas are also prohibited, and there is a religious exemption clause. SEC. 4. RELIGIOUS EXEMPTION.

This Act does not apply to religious organizations, except for employment related to for-profit activities subject to taxation.

SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. The Act grants enforcement powers to the Commission and the Librarian of Congress similar to those under other civil rights acts for claims of violations. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 grants the Board and the Attorney General powers to enforce the Act and the Government Employee Rights Act of 1991. The Employee Rights Act of 1991 grants the courts of the United States jurisdiction and powers to enforce various acts, including the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Government Employee Rights Act of 1991. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 provides procedures and remedies for claims of violations, similar to those under the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Government Employee Rights Act of 1991. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 outlines procedures and remedies for violations, including claims by covered employees for violations of the Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 provides procedures and remedies for violations, including actions against States and the United States for violations of the Act. States are not immune from federal court actions for violations, and the United States is liable for remedies under the Act to the same extent as a private person. Attorneys' fees are also addressed in the Act. Attorneys' fees may be awarded to the prevailing party in actions under the Act. Covered entities must post notices for employees and applicants. The Commission has the authority to issue regulations, and the Act's relationship to other laws is specified. SEC. 11. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER LAWS. This Act does not affect rights under title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 or any other Federal or State law. SEC. 12. SEVERABILITY. If any part of this Act is found invalid, the rest remains unaffected. SEC. 13. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act takes effect 60 days after enactment and does not apply retroactively. SEC. 14. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Commission," "covered entity," and "employer" in relation to employment laws. The Act defines key terms related to employment laws, including terms like "employment agency," "employment or employment opportunities," "labor organization," and "factors pertaining to job performance." The term "factors pertaining to job performance" includes employment history, ability to comply with performance requirements, educational background, drug/alcohol use impact, convictions for offenses with imprisonment exceeding 1 year, conflicts of interest, and seniority under a seniority system. The term "religious organization" is defined as a religious corporation, association, society, college, school, university, or educational institution controlled or supported by a religious entity, with a curriculum focused on propagating a specific religion. The term "State" is defined as per its usual meaning. The term "State" is defined in accordance with section 701(i) of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
